name: Steredenn
description: Steredenn is a frenetic and chaotic space shooter, carved in big beautiful pixels, with insane boss battles. Embark in your ship and engage the fight against dreadful space pirates in a never-ending combat for your survival.
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows XP Processor: Dual Core CPU 2.4 gHz Memory: 2048 MB RAM Graphics: Intel HD Graphics 3000, Nvidia GeForce 8000, ATI Radeon HD 4800 Series DirectX: Version 9.0 Storage: 500 MB available space

reviews.review_text: Fun at first, but gets old rather quickly. Still worth getting on sale though   The good stuff: -Music is awesome. Always enjoyable to listen to when playing, gives a good baseline for shooting things in space with some rock/metal soundtrack. -Graphics. Gorgeous pixel art is gorgeous. Well done! -Daily Runs with specific weapons and powerups. Unfortunately you can only try once, but at this point it's the only thing that maks me still paly the game occasionaly Because...  The bad stuff: Unlike other shmups where you can memorize the patterns and get better at handling certain difficult situations, by either changing your play or picking a different weapon to handle it, here you obviously can't cause it's all 'randomly' generated. So while there are specific waves that might come at one point or another in a certain level, you don't knwo for sure, and you don't know when. And some of those waves are are pretty brutal, able to take half your life in seconds if you don't react quickly.  Also, since the dropship (that has the weapons) is random, you can and will miss it a bunch, purely cause of the way the wave is structured. So that if you weren't accidentally in the right position 10 seconds before the ship shows up or don't accidentaly have a few very specific weapons you just can't get it. Combine that with wayyyy too many weapons (imo). I've played over 5 hours and haven't even seen all of them. And most of them aren't even that great or fun. A lot of quirky experimental stuff, that's just plain worse than other drops.  So often, you want/need a certain type of weapon sooner or later (like spreadshots or stuff that hits hard but is very focused) and in the end, that's what you're gonna keep and not any of the 20 other weapons that are thrown at you along the way.  Similar with the powerups at the end of the level. There are some you almsot never pick and some you absolutely want.  Now sure, one can argue, that that's the idea, that you have to learn to play with weird combos and get good at those too. Alright, if that's your thing, enjoy. But even so there's gonna be a lot of frustration coming your way, as you try and test new weapons, find yourself in unmanagable situations as a result of that and often just lose the run a few minutes later.  Last but not least. IF your'e the guy who enjoys highscoring and repeating runs for ever more points then the scoring mechanic is kind of a letdown. Most of the points (and I mean like 95% or so) come from bosses and the wave multiplier.  You get a multiplier for each wave you kill or dodge succesfuly and you lose some multiplier it whenever you get hit. But because the boss is the only thing that has a good base point value, what that means is, all you really need to do is not get hit at the boss for high scores, as IF you get to the boss you usually got a good enough multiplier on the way anyway, else you'd be dead from the waves.  So basically, scoring comes down to getting good at the bossfights and makes the rest a bit irrelevant.  Again, not my thing, but if you like that high payout at the end instead of more steady increases during the wave, then go for it. I myself wish at this point I wouldn't have spent the money on the game, because even though it was interesting at the beginning it wore out rather quickly (but just out of the 2 hours you can still ask for refund, yay)

This game has an achievement called Supernova, which unlocks when you die 50 times.  This game has an achievement called Navigator, which unlocks when you finish the game once.  Know how many people have earned Navigator? 2% of players. A mere 2% of people who have played this game have been skilled and/or lucky enough to complete it. That's it. 10% of players have achieved Supernova (*raises hand*), a number low only because 90% of people gave up on this game before it could kill them 50 times.  Steredenn, this celestial pixelated beauty, is unforgiving. It is brutality with nostalgic imagery and a transportative soundtrack. This game, this glorious, horrible game, this thing called Steredenn, will either repel you or entrance you. If you love Galaga and hate yourself, play this game. If you love pixels and outer space and shoot-em-ups, play this game. But only if you hate yourself a little bit, too.

I am not a huge fan of side scrollers or shoot em ups because I am bad at them and die very easily. I'm not a fan of the retro pixelated look either (it seems lazy). I really like this game, though. The gameplay is very smooth, and difficult but fair. You are essentially playing the same level or series of levels over and over but there is just enough variation that it doesn't get boring. Overall, I really like this game and will continue playing it for years, most likely.

Well I deleted my old review because I wanted to make a BIGGER BETTER one but not before like a smart person.  The game has a few flaws, which are simply the raw-input d-pad/keyboard control buffers (you shouldn't have any problem with a properly config'd analogue keyboard), lack of a 'focus' key, and a bit of weapon balancing. Other than that, the game is phenomenal.  Now, I grew up with mostly western shooters, like Raptor (if you buy this PLEASE get the original 1994 version and use DOSBox) and Tyrian, I did pick up Eastern shooters like R-Type and Ikaruga later in life, and found those cool too. On top of that I've played a lot of Java and Flash games that came in various flavors. I like them both for what they are and are not - gameplay, art, music, story (if applicable), etc.  This game takes both worlds of shmup, fuses them together with the French's obsession with shmups as a catalyst, and dials it up to eleven with  one of the most ♥♥♥♥awesome metal soundtracks ever made  [zandernoriega.bandcamp.com] , a grimdark story told with absolutely zero dialogue, an arsenal of well-designed weapons and upgrades that range from basic to Wild Zero, a ridiculously balanced enemy, enemy weapon, and damage sheet...  and some of the most aesthetically beautiful pieces of pixel art and animations, with layers of detail based on distance, paint-to-pixel designed, infinitely scrolling, scifi backgrounds, and super-low-detail combat sprites for less distraction and more action, as well as a helpful contrast against the incredibly detailed environments. Sure, some of that may have been due to their budget, but they're better for it.  As others may have said, it is very difficult, and that is no joke. Yes, some attacks do have patterns, but some of those 'patterns' are actually just spread/inaccuracy, so you have to account for that too. In the mean time you have artificial barriers like Laser Maze traps, including  shielded  ones, asteroid installations, shockwave ships, e-barrier ships, and lil destroyers with a 2-point damage laser that can come at you in waves of  four , all while you're being shot at with directed weapons fire from fighters, gunships with heavy blasters, and those one-two-punch 'mini' frigates. I think I forgot to mention the anti-air hazard. Yeah. Laser fire from above, in random intervals. Have you played Freespace2 at all? And accidentally got within 1.5km of a decked-out GTC Leviathan-class? Basically that. You get double score while it's active, doe.  And come loop 1, you will have enemies dropping shots on death, firing faster boolits faster (and more often than not, more boolits), and bosses dropping waves e-barriers making your life that much harder. Oh, and there's zero backup. You are 100% alone.  However, your ship is  tough . It is not to be ♥♥♥♥ed with. With effectively unlimited ammo for any weapon system, six points of armor and four points of hull, and an emergency screen powered by oncoming fire that can damage enemy ships, you can take a lot. And by a lot, I mean three hits from the Destroyer's main laser cannon tough (each hit from it does four damage). Your ship will also reconstruct itself fully using precious metals dropped by bosses. You can upgrade your armor by two points (stackable), give yourself a regenerating shield that phases you out once destroyed, buffer a bit of beam laser fire, take less damage from collisions, and even reflect damage done to you upon everyone and every thing  on-screen ('in the words of my generation: UP. YOURRRRRRRSSS!'), given you chance these perks from a boss, OR equip yourself with one of two defensive weapon systems that either protect you from all damage or reflect enemy boolits (this one can obliterate a Battleship in nothing flat).  Don't even get me started on weapons. But I will say, yes, it  does  have The Only Way To Be Sure™. Lastly, you'll notice an achievement called 'ULTRAWARRIOR,' for beating the game with just the Good Blaster At Your Side. It is possible. I've done it, and I'm not even that good and have a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ controler (F310 with faulty sticks). Do not, I repeat:  do not  underestimate the Blaster.  Whether you are a danmaku master or a western shmup connoisseur, you will have your hands absolutely full. ♥♥♥♥ yes this game is hard, but it is the  best  kind of hard:  This game is 100% adrenaline.

Not a bad mindless game. I like to have it on half the monitor screen while watching shows in the other half. Can be frustrating at times. I got it in the Humble Bundle Monthly deal. Not sure I would pay more than $10 for it, but fun for what it is.

One of my favourite SHMUPs. Responsive, difficult (but fair), cool weapons and variety, kickass music.  The game never ends, once you beat the final boss, it starts over but with more and faster enemy bullets, more difficult waves and the bosses start using shields. The graphics are very clear and even with a lot of stuff on the screen its fairly easy to see what is going on. Took me a long time to beat but when I did the feeling was great, even looped the game once.

Great game.  I may just be submitting this review for the Steam Awards 2016, but out of the nine games I nominated, I felt this one deserved it the most.  Nominated the game for the 'I thought this game was cool before it won an award' category for two reasons: -There is a similiar quote in the game -I first saw the game played by Bisnap on YouTube when it was still in early access and knew it was cool back then.

A really nice horizontal shoot'em up with lots of different weapons, some crazier than others (you don't often get a drill or a sword as a weapon for a spaceship!) Quite challenging, without being a bullet hell either, at least not in the beginning.
Decent gameplay, rpg element is a plus, great music, absolutely terrible in terms of scoring mechanics.

Should you buy this game? ABSOLUTELY.  TLDR: Great weapon upgrades, great enemies / variety of enemies, RNG is well balanced, key bindings / HUD / Menu are fantastic and clean, replayability is incredibly nice, graphics are fantastic, game runs 100% fine even on crappy laptops, 0 space consumption on the download, NO frustrating elements to the game WHATSOEVER (not even on death), music is wonderful, perfect pick up and everything you'd expect you'd be buying and more for these genres!   ______________________  This game is phenomenal! EVERYONE should have this if they're a fan of these types of bullet hell space games. The content is great, the replayability is great, the graphics are fantastic, the characters / ships aren't annoying or overly done, the weapons are very unique (Huge jaw that can bite enemies? SWEET!), and much more. As someone who is rather picky with my purchaces and tests games out on an old crappy laptop BEFORE using them on my good one, I can say I'm very satisfied with this game. It runs great on any old laptop and especially the newer ones. The only thing that's a slight, slight pain is that bosses and certain enemies can have REALLY fast attacks that are incredibly hard to dodge without prior knowledge of what they do and how their patterns work, so it can be tough to play through on your first couple runs. Although, that's to be expected. That being said, it's NOT overly difficult to learn, and there's DEFINITELY not a super, super steep / frustrating learning curve. It's done just right.   It's everything you'd expect you'd be getting and more. What's especially nice is the crazy support for key bindings (mouse friendly) and controllers! More game companies need to get in this habbit. It's so refreshing not to find myself frustrated with annoying controls or lack of controller usage.

Fun little space based shooter. Plenty of upgrades and powerups to play around with, and an excellent FTL-esque artstyle to boot.  Enemies are nicely varied, with different strengths/weaknesses that your weapons will deal with, and there's enough random generation per level that dying and going back to level 1 doesn't feel like a grind.

Super fun schmup! Even the dieing is fun!  Crazy duel weapon system with perks; pick a power up after every 'boss fight'.  Fight the bosses in arena mode with your choice of weapons that you've encountered.  Daily challenges and leaderboards!  I just wish there was more of the music and a soundtrack to play externally.  Oh did I mention the pixel art is fantastic?

Pros : - Great soundtrack , very energetic  - controls well , very slick responsive - bullet hell galore - absolutley great looking pixel design - enjoyable weapons  cons:  - unfair as ♥♥♥♥ for the first time player - Im a souls series veteran , and I tought myself to look and study patterns and I rarely 'rage' in unfair situations but this game really smacks new comers across the face . you wont be able to react and dodge most early game bosses' attacks until youve been hit by them a couple of times .  for example : boss shoots medium speed medium size projectiles , all good and dandy suddenly goes to the center of the screen and shoots ultra fast projectiles that killed me right away , only way to dodge them is to know they are coming. - Soundtrack is good but gets repetitive quick. - AI's projectiles will often force you against a screen wall and hit you without giving you a chance to dodge - a boss shot at me in a trident shape way and caught me between the middle and bottom beams , continued to slide down to the bottom of the screen and killing me.   overall this game is worth checking out , not surprised how praised it is in the reviews even though it might be a tad to 'hardcore' even for rougelike\bullet hell\RNG game veterans who visit the game for the first time

Loved this game I've played it for hours! It is a mix between a old arcade bullet hell, and a new style rogue-like. You should get it no matter what you like thats why we have steam refund if you hate it.(But you won't, you'll love it)

Watching the trailers and enjoying the pretty visuals, I was doubtful about the gameplay. I've played sidescrolling space shooters before, and they got old pretty fast despite looking good. I bought this game fully expecting to have it refunded within half an hour or so.  Well, nice going, you managed to keep my interest for well beyond that point. Loving this game. I've managed to get up to #16-ish on the daily run a couple times now, but despite that I've yet to actually beat the game once.

This is procedurally generated SHUMP is probably my new favorite thing for a while. A combination of upgrades, multitudes of different weapons, heart pounding music, fast skilled gameplay, and kickass graphics.   Thanks for stealing my evenings Steredenn.
WARNING!!! If you do not like orange with a hint of black, please leave, now!   R-Type, bullethell, shmup, twinstick, rogueplay and 1CC. The question is: Will it blend ?
This game is my go-to game when i just need to sit, play something, be entertained, and enjoy everything it throws at me.  Amazing presentation, wonderful soundtrack, and highly recommended.
Polished and interesting, but the difficulty is just way too hard.

I'd more describe this as a procedural game than an actual roguelike, but thats by the by. What it is though, is nails hard and a lot of fun. Great mix of weapons and upgrades, excellent pixel graphics and awesome sound track. Certainly one to own if you like shmups

Not really my kind of game, fairly boring and repetitive without any kind of sense of achievement. The intro video pretty much shows the whole game, so if you're looking for anything deeper than what you see there, I'd suggest looking elsewhere

The thing you have to ask yourself about this Shmup is 'do the rogue-like elements improve the gamplay?'. And I don't think they do. Despite each wave and level being randomly generated,hilariously, they mostly feel the same. It's just a slog through space, fighting gray cubes until you can fight the big gray cube at the end.  There are some exeptions, like the asteroid belt level and space debris level, but once I've destroyed the boss cube, I pretty much forget everything leading up to that point. Throw in a bunch of weapons and powerups that mostly serve as novelties and you'll quickly realize that once you try to get serious about progressing in this game, 9 times out of 10, you'll be ill equipped to handle the steep challenge.  All in all, this feels more like a bonus mode that would have been included ina much larger game. I would reccomend sticking to the hundreds of free shmups you can find on Newgrounds or Kongregate.
I got mad and was happy about it. I suck, game rocks.

Why I RECOMMEND, yet, RUFUNDED my purchase :T. I love everything about this game! From its graphics to its mechanics and downright to its music. This game is pure joy. But, its dependency on HEAVY rouge-like elements absoultely kills it for me. If the game relyed more on skill and understanding of the (little, but simple) mechanics/patterns rather then getting lucky with weapon drops on/and with boss encounters I would of have kept my purchase. It was clear that just about all my deaths were because of bad drops which is, unfournately, the nature of rouge-likes. Which is a shame because this a fantastic Shoot'em Up! But, I can only recommend this game to those who have tolorence over rouge-likes. Personally, I am quite finished with heavily rouge-like inspired games and its nature of 'randomness'. I have already gotten a refund, and plan to buy this game when it is on sale, and for when I feel like playing burning through another rouge-like.
Holy ♥♥♥♥, this game is intense, and awesome! Great soundtrack, insane weapons and bosses, it's just awesome! If you love side-scrolling shooter bullet hell, this is one game you need.

Original: Not sure how this is even possible to beat.  Expanded:  Okay I'll clarify. Many of these points were summarized in other reviews so I didn’t really put much effort into the review. I apologize.  Steredenn has fantastic graphics, audio, atmosphere, and variety and it really drew me in when I started playing it and I still love these aspects of the game. However the game punishes players very hard for anything less than a perfect performance. On top of that there is a function of luck involved in beating the game because only a few items and upgrades are helpful in progressing through the levels and bosses. There is no permanent progression or anything like that so when you do lose its back to start. It is frustrating because the game is so punishing I'm not able to see the rest of the game. I would love to see all the different and unique enemies of the moderate and higher levels but it is effectively blocked to more novice and even intermediate players. The further you make it the more unenjoyable it seems to become because of the looming punishment of losing all progress. If you’re a hardcore side scrolling shooter fan you will love this game it is worth will be for you. If you’re anything less than hardcore you will have a tough time getting through the game. Steredenn is 13$ currently and that’s fine given its high quality but for being unable to enjoy most of it I can’t recommend it. If they added even a teeny tiny minor element of permanent progression I would change this to a recommendation in a heartbeat. Mabey by unlocking different ships with slightly different characteristics or configurations; Or by keeping a fraction of effects from upgrades acquired from boss fights. It can be anything really but playing this as it is feels like beating my head against a wall. Hell you can even make these changes in a side mode and keep the main game as is and I would be cool with it. Wishful thinking for now but maybe in the future they’ll add some of this to it. I never write reviews but I did for this game because it is so close to being an amazing game for me.

The game has potential to be great. The graphics, music and sounds are very well done. What makes me unable to recommend the game is the difficulty. Within 30 seconds of starting the game, I was thrust into situations harder than some of the boss fights in a shooter like Ikaruga.   For me, it just feels too tedious and grindy. A game like Rogue Legacy hits the mark of being kind of grindy while still having enough content to be fun. The content here got old after about ten minutes, and then it is just bullet hell on repeat.  Will appeal to hard core shooter fans, and people who like arcade style 'set the highest score' games, but it is not my kind of game.
Your gun's bullet casings fall down even though there's no gravity. Literally unplayable.

I like this game, it's pretty fun but I was expecting to like it a lot more than I actually do I really like shoot em up games, with power ups and screens full of bullets but this game  just lacks that addictive quality for me. I can't quite put my finger on why but I just don't like  this game as much as I really should.  However I do reccomend for other to try

This game is one hell of a ride. I've never been great at this type of game, but that doesn't stop me from diving back in again and again. It's easy to find a couple favourite weapons, but if you let yourself explore all of the options, you'll find joy in almost all of them. The bosses are similar; you'll have early nemeses, but eventually grow to know them and love conquering them. You'll easily get your money's worth.
